moves.1. e4: In this game I win quickly with a standard sacrifice - however I found out during analysis that it is not sound!
moves.1... e6: He plays the French Defence. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Defence
moves.2. d4: I didn't really want to play in this match, but a player dropped out a few days before.
moves.2... d5: It was in Division 3 of the Chester & District Chess League.
moves.3... Bb4: This is the Winawer Variation. Black pins the Nc3 and threatens d5xe4. It is named after Szymon Winawer and pioneered by Nimzowitsch and Botvinnik
moves.4. e5: The normal reply,  gaining space and hoping to show that Black's b4-bishop is misplaced.
moves.5. a3: Also usual, play normally continues Bxc3+ 6. bxc3, but...
moves.5... cxd4: My book on The French Defence, by Glogoric, Uhlmann, Botvinnik and Karpov says that this move has "almost disappeared from tournament practice".
moves.7. bxc3: I took back, almost without thinking. My book mentions 7. Nf3 or 7. Qg4 as the usual moves here, but to me this simply recapture looked normal. Using an opening database, I see that those two moves are more popular, but don't necessarily score better.
moves.7... Qc7: This is the drawback with the move - black goes a pawn up anyway. However white has enough compensation.
moves.8. Nf3: The most popular move, but I found out later that 8. f4 scores better. I wanted to get on with my development.
moves.9. Bd2: The only move on my opening databases.
moves.9... Qc7: The queen drops back. Again the only move in my databases.
moves.10. Bd3: I continue to develop. I have compensation for the pawn in better development, and a lovely half open a file.
moves.11... O-O: He follows suit, but at the time I thought it was a mistake.
moves.12. Bxh7+: In the 14 games on Gameknot that this position was reached, only one game featured this standard sacrifice - gtemple (2061) vs. serj_md (1789) Started: 02-Sep-13, Ended: 26-Sep-13. My version of Fritz prefers 12. Re1, we will see why soon.
moves.12... Kxh7: He takes. I thought at the time 12....Kh8 was the only way to continue, after all as he was  pawn up before, he is still level on material. I was wrong.
moves.13. Ng5+: I throw in a check. Now what we both missed at the time was 13....Kg8 14. Qh5 (threatening mate on h7) Qxc2! and black covers the mating square h7, with advantage to black!
moves.13... Kg6: Luckily for me, he tries this.
moves.14. Qg4:
With the threat of mate with 15. Nxe6 Kh7 16. Qxg7. Fritz thinks 14.....f5 is best, when 15. Qh4 leads to a advantage of plus 2.88 to white, although I would have been tempted by the simpler f5
15.	Nxe6+	fxg4
16.	Nxc7	followed by Nxa8.
moves.14... Nf5: He tries this, which saves his king (at least in the short term)
moves.15. Nxe6+: But not his queen. Black resigns. Thank you for reading, please leave a comment or two and rate my annotation on the star system. Until next time dear reader!

players: Charles L Higgie (ECF161) vs. Steve Richards (ECF115)
